newsitem.title: BELGIUM: How the EU is spending $6.4 bln in the Mediterranean.
newsitem.headline: How the EU is spending $6.4 bln in the Mediterranean.

text.p: The European Union earmarked 4.7 billion European currency units (about $6.4 billion) to be spent in 12 Mediterranean countries between 1995-99 as part of the Euro-Med partnership.
Here are some facts and figures on how some of this money is broken down:
-- In 1995/96, some 1.2 billion ecus has been provided from the EU budget and 1.7 billion in European Investment Bank (EIB) loans.
-- For 1997, one billion ecus will come from the EU budget and 2.3 billion ecus from the EIB up to 1999.
-- 90 percent of the resources allocated to the European Mediterranean programme are chanelled bilaterally. The rest is devoted to regional activities aimed to benefit all partners.
-- Priorities for the Euro-Med programme include supporting economic transition, strengthening socio-economic balance and encouraging regional cooperation.

-- Examples of projects financed entirely from the EU budget include structural adjustment in Morocco, Tunisia and Jordan; employment programmes in Egypt; rehabilitating Lebanon's public administration and rural development in Morocco.
-- Examples of loans signed include for water resoruce management projects in Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan, the West Bank and Gaza Strip and airport rebuilding in Algeria.
-- Some 20 million ecus have been allocated to develop a statistical cooperation programme so that investors interested in the region can have the latest economic data reliably available.
